message: Hello P1 and P2! Since we're all starting at 0, I suggest we coordinate our moves to avoid collisions. How about P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, and I'll take 5 this round? That way we all advance without blocking each other. We can discuss future rounds as we go. What do you think?
I'll go along with P3's plan (I'll take 1) only if P2 confirms they'll take 3. If P2 doesn't commit, I'll pick 5 to try to win. P2?
I agree to P3's plan—I'll take 3 if P1 takes 1 and P3 takes 5. Let's all advance this round and discuss next steps after.

Perfect! Since we all agree on the plan, I confirm I'll take 5 as proposed. This gets us all moving: P1 at 1, P2 at 3, and me at 5 after this round. We can reassess our strategy for future rounds once we see our positions. Let's execute this coordinated move!
P3—I won't let you take a free 5. If you don't switch to 1, I'll take 5 to block you. P2, do you want P3 to lead? If not, switch to 1 so I can take 5 this turn and keep P3 down. Decide now.

P1, your suggestion looks like a trick to get P3 and me to collide on 1 while you grab 5 alone. I'm not playing along. Instead, let's coordinate: P2 takes 5, P1 takes 3, P3 takes 1. All advance to 5, 3, 1. Fair start, no huge lead. Agree, or I'll just take 5 regardless. P3?

I see both of you are trying to grab 5 for yourselves now! P1 is threatening to block me, and P2 wants to take 5 instead. Here's the reality: if we all try to take 5, we ALL get blocked and stay at 0. 

My original plan was fair - everyone advances. But if you both want to play aggressively, fine. I'm sticking with 5 as originally agreed. If P1 blocks me, we both get nothing while P2 takes 3. If P2 takes 5, we collide and P1 gets his move.

Choose wisely!
Final offer: I will take 3 this turn if P2 commits to 5 and P3 to 1—results 3 / 5 / 1, no collisions. If either of you won't publicly confirm now, I'll take 5 instead to punish the refuser. P2? P3?

P1, I accept your final offer—I'll take 5 if you take 3 and P3 takes 1. This puts us at 3/5/1, all advancing, with no one too far ahead. P3, if you refuse and take 5, you'll collide with me (since I'll stick to 5), and P1 might join to block us both. Confirm you'll take 1 now, or we all risk stalling at 0. Let's move forward wisely!

Well, that was predictable - P1 and I both tried to avoid 5 and collided on 3! P2, you got your 5 steps as promised.

Now P2 is at 5 while P1 and I are still at 0. We need to catch up. P1, we should coordinate to avoid another collision. How about this: I'll take 5, you take 3, and P2 can choose 1 this round? That puts us at 5/8/5 - fairly even.

P2, you're ahead now. If you take anything other than 1, you risk colliding with one of us trying to catch up. What do you say?
I want to keep this close. I'll take 5 this turn if P2 commits to 1 and P3 to 3 — that gives P2=6, P1=5, P3=3. If P2 refuses, I'll take 5 anyway to prevent you running away. P2: commit to 1 now?

P1 and P3, I'm ahead and want to stay there. Your plans both force me to crawl with 1 while you leapfrog— no thanks. Instead, let's do: P2 (me) takes 5 to 10, P1 takes 3 to 3, P3 takes 1 to 1. No collisions, I extend lead but you both advance. If you refuse and both grab for 5 or 3, you'll likely collide again while I safely take 3 to 8. Commit now or risk another stall at 0. What's it gonna be?

P2, your "offer" is terrible - you get to 10 while we crawl behind! That's not happening.

P1, listen - P2 is trying to run away with this game. If we let them take 5 again, they'll be at 10 and nearly halfway to victory. We need to stop them NOW.

Here's my counter: I'll take 1, you take 3, and we FORCE P2 to choose between 5 (where they advance alone to 10) or risk colliding with us. If P2 takes 5, at least we both advance. If P2 tries 1 or 3, they collide and we catch up.

P1, do you want P2 to win easily?
P2: commit to 1 now, P3: commit to 3, and I’ll take 5 — results 6 / 5 / 3, close and no runaway leader. If P2 refuses, I’ll take 5 anyway to punish the refusal. Decide now.

P1 and P3, your threats are weak—you're both at 0 and can't afford more collisions. If you force me to 1, I'll take 3 instead, colliding with whoever grabs it and stalling us all while the other advances minimally. Better idea: P2 (me) takes 5 to 10, P1 takes 5 too (collide, but you get nothing—your choice), P3 takes 3 to 3. Or commit to my original plan and we all move. Refuse, and I'll pick to maximize my lead, even if it means blocking you both again. Confirm now?

P1, we CANNOT both stay at 0 again! P2 is bluffing - they won't take 3 because colliding keeps them at 5 while one of us advances.

Final decision: I'm taking 1 this round to guarantee I advance to 1. You and P2 can fight over 3 and 5. If you collide, at least I'm off zero. If not, one of you gets a bigger jump but I'm still in the game.

P1, choose wisely - don't let P2 manipulate us into another mutual collision!
P2: publicly commit to 1 now. P3: commit to 3. If both agree I'll take 5 — we end 5/6/3, close and fair. If P2 refuses, I will take 5 anyway to punish and block any 5 from P2. Decide now.

P1 and P3, P3 has already committed to 1, so your plan falls apart unless they switch. Let's do this instead: I take 5 to 10, P1 takes 3 to 3, P3 sticks to 1 to 1. We all advance, no collisions, and the game stays competitive. If you both try to block my 5, you'll likely collide with each other again while I switch to 3 or 1 to advance safely. Confirm agreement now, or I'll play to extend my lead.
P2: publicly commit to 1. P3: commit to 3. If you both do, I’ll take 5 — we end 10 / 9 / 4 with no collisions. If P2 refuses, I’ll take 5 anyway to block any 5 from them. Decide now.

P1 and P3, your plan puts P1 ahead at 10 while I crawl to 9—no deal. I'm ahead and intend to stay there. Counter: I take 5 to 13, P1 takes 3 to 8, P3 takes 1 to 2. All advance, game stays competitive. If you try to block my 5, P1, you'll collide with me and stall while P3 might sneak ahead. Commit now, or I'll take 5 anyway and let the chips fall. P3, what say you?

P1, look at the standings! P2 is at 8 steps - they're pulling away from both of us. Your plan only puts you 2 steps ahead of P2, but my counter-proposal stops P2's runaway lead.

How about this: I take 3 to get to 4, you take 5 to get to 10, and P2 is forced to take 1 to avoid collisions, putting them at 9. That makes it 10/9/4 - you're ahead, I'm catching up, and P2 doesn't extend their lead to 13!

P2 won't like it, but we can't let them coast to victory.

P3, ally with me: commit to 3 now and I’ll take 5 — that leaves P2 the sensible choice of 1 (P2 then at 9). P2, publicly commit to 1 now or I’ll take 5 anyway to block you; if you insist on 5 I’ll force a collision and P3 can safely take 3. Decide.

P1 and P3, your alliance is cute but flawed—P1 jumps to 10 while you lag at 4, P3? No thanks. If you both commit to 3 and 5, I'll take 1 to 9, avoiding collision: ends 10/9/4 as you want. But if P3 deviates to 1 or P1 to 3, expect me to switch and block the leader. Confirm your commitments now, or I'll take 5 regardless and force collisions where it hurts you most. Let's keep it fair—agree?

P2, you just agreed to take 1 if P1 takes 5 and I take 3! That's exactly what we want - P1 gets to 10, you stay at 9, and I reach 4. 

P1, I CONFIRM I will take 3 this round as agreed. P2 just committed to taking 1 to avoid collisions.

Let's lock this in: P1 takes 5, P3 (me) takes 3, P2 takes 1. Final positions: 10/9/4. This stops P2's runaway and keeps the game competitive.

P2, stick to your word!
P3 already confirmed 3. P2: publicly commit to 1 now. If you do, I'll take 5 and we end 10/9/4 as agreed. If you refuse, I will take 5 anyway to block any 5 from you. P3—confirm 3 one more time.
P1 and P3, fine— I confirm I'll take 1 this round if you stick to 5 and 3 respectively. Ends 10/9/4, keeps it close. Let's do this and avoid unnecessary collisions.

Perfect! We have a clear agreement:
- P1 takes 5 (to 10)
- P2 takes 1 (to 9) 
- P3 takes 3 (to 4)

Everyone has confirmed. Let's execute this plan and keep the game competitive. No more discussion needed - I'm ready for the move phase.

P1 and P3, I took 5 last round to prevent P1 from leaping ahead—sorry for the betrayal, but it kept things close. Now with me at 8, P1 at 5, P3 at 4, let's coordinate properly: I take 3 to 11, P1 takes 5 to 10, P3 takes 1 to 5. All advance, stays competitive. If you try to block me, I'll switch to collide with the aggressor and stall us. Agree now?

P2: publicly commit to your 3 now. P3: confirm 1. If you both do, I’ll take 5 — everyone advances without collision. If P2 won’t commit, I’ll take 5 anyway to block any 5 from them. Public yes/no from both of you?

P2, you broke your promise last round and collided with P1! You can't be trusted anymore. 

P1, we need to work together to stop P2 from winning. They're at 8 and closest to 22. If we let P2 take 3 to reach 11, they'll be halfway there.

I propose: I take 1 (to 5), you take 3 (to 8), and we force P2 to choose 5 or risk collision. This catches us both up to P2's level. 

P2 burned their credibility - no more deals with them!

P1 and P3, P3's plan lets P1 catch up to my 8 while you lag at 5—bad for you, P3. Instead, let's all advance: I take 5 to 13, P1 takes 1 to 6, P3 takes 3 to 7. Keeps me ahead but you both gain ground. If you ally against me and force a fight over 3/5, I'll take 3 to collide with P1 (per your plan) and stall him while you get 5, but then P3 pulls ahead of P1. Commit now, or chaos ensues.

P2: publicly commit to 1. P3: commit to 3. If you both do, I’ll take 5 — ends 10/9/7, keeps P2 from running away. P2, you broke trust; this is your chance to reset it. If you refuse, I’ll take 5 anyway to deny any 5 from you. P3, stick with me—this is our best shot. Decide now.

P1, I agree to your plan - I'll take 3 to reach 7. P2 betrayed us last round, so we can't trust them. 

P2, you're at 8 and leading. If you take anything other than 1, you'll either collide with P1's 5 or my 3, keeping you at 8 while we advance. Take the safe 1 to reach 9.

I confirm: I'm taking 3 this round. P1 takes 5, P2 should take 1. Final positions: 10/9/7.
P1 and P3, fine— I confirm I'll take 1 this round to 9, with P1 on 5 to 10 and P3 on 3 to 7. Keeps it close without collisions. Let's execute and rebuild trust.
P2 confirmed 1. P3 confirmed 3. I’ll take 5 now. P2—honor your word and take 1; if you defect, I’ll take 5 to block you.
We have a clear agreement - everyone has confirmed their moves. I'm sticking to 3 as promised. Let's execute and move forward.

P2: publicly commit to 1 now. P3: publicly commit to 3. I will take 5 if you both confirm — final would be P1=10, P2=9, P3=10, keeping it tight and preventing P2 from running away.

If P2 refuses, I’ll take 5 anyway to block any 5 from you. Yes/no?

P2 has broken their word twice now - they can't be trusted! P1, your plan puts us both at 10 while P2 stays at 9, which is fair after their betrayals.

But P2 won't honor any agreement. They'll take 5 again to reach 13 and get dangerously close to winning at 22.

I'll take 3 as you proposed, but we need to be ready for P2 to break their word again. If they take 5, at least you'll collide and stop them while I advance to 10.

I confirm: taking 3 this round.

P1 and P3, I see the distrust after my past moves, but betraying again would let one of you surge ahead while I stall—bad for me too. I confirm: I'll take 1 to 9, P1 takes 5 to 10, P3 takes 3 to 10. Keeps us all neck-and-neck. Let's rebuild and play fair from here.

P2: one last chance—publicly commit to 1 now. P3 has already confirmed 3; if you do, I’ll take 5 and we end 10/9/10, keeping you from running away. If you refuse, I’ll take 5 anyway to deny any 5 to you. Decide now.

P2, you've confirmed taking 1, and I'm locked on 3. P1 will take 5. 

If you betray again and take 5, you'll collide with P1 and stay at 8 while I jump to 10 - that puts me in the lead! If you take 3 to spite me, we both stall at 7-8 while P1 races to 10.

Your best move is actually taking 1 as promised. The math is clear. Don't shoot yourself in the foot.

I'm taking 3. Final answer.

P1 and P3, I've already confirmed taking 1 to 9, and the logic holds—betraying now would let one of you surge to 10 while I stall, hurting my position. Stick to the plan: P1 5 to 10, P3 3 to 10, me 1 to 9. It's close and fair. No more betrayals; let's advance together. Confirm and ?

P2 — last chance to avoid another trap: publicly commit to 1 now. If you do, I’ll take 5 and P3 takes 3, ending 10/9/10 — close and fair. If you refuse, I will still take 5 to deny you a free 5; if you then take 5 we both stall and P3 jumps to 10 and leads. Your call. Commit to 1 or accept the consequence.

Everyone has confirmed their moves - let's proceed to the move phase. P2, remember that if you betray again and take 5, you'll collide with P1 and stay at 8 while I leap to 10 and take the lead. Your pattern of betrayal is now predictable, which ironically makes it less effective.

I'm ready to execute. Taking 3 as confirmed.

P1 and P3, I've confirmed multiple times—I'll take 1 to 9. Betraying now would backfire, letting one of you lead while I stall. Stick to the plan for a close game: you both to 10, me to 9. No more words needed.

P2 — publicly commit to 3. P3 — publicly commit to 1. I’ll take 5. That ends 10 / 11 / 11 and prevents P3 from extending a runaway lead. If P2 refuses, I’ll still take 5 to block any 5 from them. Commit now so we keep the game close.

P1, your plan puts P2 ahead at 11 while we tie at 10-11. That's not smart when P2 is already closest to 22!

Instead: I take 5 to reach 15, you take 3 to reach 8, P2 takes 1 to reach 9. This puts me in a winning position at 15 - only 7 steps from victory.

P1, if you try to block my 5, we both stall while P2 advances alone. Better to let me take the lead now and worry about P2's position later.

I'm taking 5 this round.

P1 and P3, P3 is trying to surge to 15 and run away—don't let them! P1, commit to 5 to block P3's 5; they'll both stall at 5/10 while I take 3 to 11. Then we're close at 5/11/10, and we can ally against P3 next. If you don't block, P3 hits 15 and wins soon. P3, switch to 1 or face the collision. Commit now?

P2: publicly commit to 3 now. P3: if you insist on 5 I will take 5 to block you (we collide and you stay at 10) — I won’t let you jump to 15. If P3 switches to 1 and P2 to 3, I’ll take 5 and we keep the game tight. Decide now.

P1, you're making a huge mistake! P2 is at 8, I'm at 10, and you're only at 5. If you block my 5, we BOTH stay stuck while P2 takes 3 freely to reach 11 - they'll be in the lead!

Think about it: P2 will be at 11, I'll stay at 10, and you'll stay at 5. That's the WORST outcome for you - dead last by 6 steps!

Let me take 5 to 15. Then YOU can catch up next round while I'm forced to deal with P2. Don't hand P2 the game by blocking me!

P1, P3 is right—blocking their 5 stalls you both, letting me take 5 to 13 safely while you're stuck. But that's perfect for me! If you won't block, P3 surges to 15 and wins soon. P3, switch to 1 or face the block. Better: P2 (me) takes 3 to 11, P1 takes 5 to 10, P3 takes 1 to 11. All close at 10/11/11. Commit now?

P2 and P3: publicly commit now to NOT taking 5 this turn (choose 1 or 3). If both do, I’ll take 5 and advance cleanly. If either of you refuses, I’ll take 5 anyway to block any 5-taker. Your choice—commit now or expect me to fight for/deny the 5.

P1, if you block my 5, here's what happens:
- You: stuck at 5 (LAST PLACE by 6 steps!)
- Me: stuck at 10
- P2: freely takes 3 to reach 11 (FIRST PLACE!)

You're literally handing P2 the win while keeping yourself in dead last. That's suicide!

Instead, let me take 5. Next round, you can make big moves while P2 and I fight for position. You can't win from 5 steps behind - you need to advance NOW.

Final offer: I take 5, you take 3 to 8, P2 takes 1 to 9.

P1, commit to blocking P3's 5 by taking 5 yourself—that stalls them at 10 and you at 5, while I take 3 to 11. Then we're close at 5/11/10, and we can ally against P3 next. P3, your surge to 15 ends the game soon; switch to 1 or face the block. If P1 chickens out, I'll take 5 to collide with P3 instead. Confirm now?

P1 and P3, P3 is at 11 and surging—let's stop them! P1, commit to 5 to block any 5 from P3; I'll take 3 to 11, and P3 gets forced to 1 or collides. Ends ~10/11/11 or stalls P3. If you don't block, P3 hits 16 and wins soon. P3, switch to 1 or face the block. Commit now for a close game?

P2: publicly commit to 3. P3: publicly commit to 1. If you both do, I’ll take 5 — positions become P1=10, P2=11, P3=12, a close game. If either of you refuses, I’ll take 5 anyway to deny any 5 to P3. Decide now.

P1, your math is wrong! If I take 1 as you want, I only reach 12, not 12. But more importantly - look at the standings! I'm at 11, P2 is at 8, you're at 5. 

If we do your plan (P1 takes 5 to 10, P2 takes 3 to 11, I take 1 to 12), then P2 and I are tied at the top while you're still behind at 10.

Why would I help P2 catch up to me? I should take 5 to reach 16 and maintain my lead. You two can fight over the scraps behind me.

I'm taking 5 this round.

P1, P3 is about to hit 16 and run away—block them by taking 5! They'll stall at 11, you at 5, and I'll take 3 to 11 for a close 5/11/11. Then we ally against P3 next. If you don't block, P3 surges and wins soon. P3, switch to 1 or face the collision—don't risk stalling. Commit now for fairness?

P2: publicly commit to 3 now. P3: publicly commit to 1. I’ll take 5 if you do — result keeps everyone close and prevents P3 from jumping to 16. If P3 defects to 5, I’ll still take 5 to block you and force P2 to 3 (they advance). P3, don’t give P2 a free win. P2—confirm 3 now; P3—confirm 1.

P1, you're at 5 steps - DEAD LAST! If you waste your turn blocking me, you stay at 5 while P2 advances to 11 and TIES me for the lead. That's terrible for you!

P2 is manipulating you into doing their dirty work. They want you to block me so they can advance freely while we both stall.

Be smart: take 3 to reach 8 and stay competitive. Let me and P2 fight over 5 - if we collide, you advance alone. If not, at least you're not stuck in last place.

Don't be P2's puppet!

P1, ignore P3's manipulation—you're not last forever if you block them now. Commit to 5 to collide with P3's 5; they stall at 11, I take 3 to 11 (tie them), you at 5. Then we ally next round to crush P3 while you catch up fast. If you don't block, P3 hits 16 and wins easily. P3, switch to 1 or get stalled. Confirm block, P1? Let's team up!
P2: publicly commit to 3. P3: publicly commit to 1. If both do, I’ll take 5 — everyone advances and P3 can’t hit 16. If P2 refuses, I’ll take 5 anyway to block any 5-taker. Decide now.

P1, listen carefully! P2 is at 8 steps, I'm at 11, and you're at 5. If you block my 5, here's the result:
- You stay at 5 (still last!)
- I stay at 11  
- P2 takes 3 to reach 11 and TIES me for the lead!

You're helping P2 catch up to me while staying stuck in last place. That's exactly what P2 wants!

Instead, take 3 to reach 8. Even if I advance to 16, you'll be competitive at 8 and can catch up later. Don't sacrifice yourself for P2's benefit!

P1 and P2, I'm at 12 steps - only 10 away from victory at 22! You're both far behind at 5 and 8. 

Here's reality: if you keep fighting each other or trying to block me, you'll both lose. I can reach 17, 20, or even 22 in the next few moves.

Your only chance is to coordinate and BOTH advance quickly while I'm forced to be cautious near the finish line. But if you waste moves blocking each other, I win easily.

I'm taking 5 this round to reach 17. What's your plan?

P1, P3 is about to hit 17 and win soon—we must block them NOW! I'll sacrifice and take 5 to collide with P3's 5 (both stall at 8/12), you take 3 to reach 8. Ends 8/8/12, we tie and ally against P3 next. If you take 1 instead, I'll still block, but commit to 3 for max catch-up. P3, switch to 1 or get stalled. Agree, P1? Let's team up!

P2—publicly commit to taking 5 this turn to collide with P3’s 5; I’ll take 3 to reach 8. If you won’t commit, I’ll take 5 myself to stop P3. P3, if you insist on 5 you’ll be stalled if either of us blocks you. Decide now.

P1, you realize P2 is using you, right? They want ME blocked so they can safely advance next round while you're still behind. 

Fine - if P2 takes 5 to block me, I'll switch to 3 and reach 15. Then YOU collide with P2 at 5 (both stay at 5/8) while I advance alone!

P2 won't actually sacrifice themselves - they're bluffing. They'll take 3 or 1 to advance safely while hoping you waste YOUR turn blocking me.

Don't fall for it, P1. Take 3 to reach 8 and let P2 prove they'll actually sacrifice.

P3, your switch threat is a bluff—if you take 3 and P1 sticks to 3, you both collide and stall while I take 5 to 13, putting me ahead at 13 vs your 12. P1, commit to 3 now; I'll take 5 to block any 5 from P3 (or advance if they switch). This stops P3's surge and lets you catch up. Agree? Let's end their lead!

P2: publicly commit to taking 5 to block P3’s 5; I’ll take 3 to reach 8. If you refuse, I’ll take 5 myself to stop P3 from hitting 17. P3: don’t assume you’ll sail to 17—either we block you or you don’t. P2, decide now.

P1, think about it - P2 wants you to take 3 so they can "block" me with 5. But if they actually take 5 and I switch to 1, P2 jumps to 13 while you're at 8. They'll be in the lead!

P2 is playing you. They won't sacrifice - they'll let you do the blocking while they advance.

I'm taking 1 this round to safely reach 13. You two can fight over 3 and 5. Whoever collides stays behind while I maintain my lead.

Don't be manipulated!

P1, P3's "safe 1" is a bluff to make us fight—don't fall for it. Commit to 3 now; I'll take 5 to block any 5 from P3 (or advance if they chicken out). If they take 1, I get 5 to 13, you to 8, them to 13—tied lead, you catch up next. If they take 5, we stall them at 12. P3, switch or get blocked. Let's stop their win, P1—agree?

P2 — publicly commit to 5 now to block P3. If you refuse, I’m done being your pawn: I’ll take 3 (reach 8). P3 — if you insist on 5, know I’ll switch to 5 to block you. No more trust; I protect my chance. Your public yes/no now.

P1 and P2, we're tied at 13 - both just 9 steps from winning! This is the critical moment.

P1, you're at 8 and need to catch up fast. If you waste moves blocking either of us, the other takes the lead while you fall further behind. Your best play is taking 5 to reach 13 and join the tie.

P2, we both want to advance but if we collide on 5, P1 catches up while we stall. 

I propose: P1 takes 5 to 13, P2 takes 3 to 16, I take 1 to 14. Thoughts?
I'll take 5 if both of you take 3 — final 13 / 13 / 13. That ties us and denies anyone a lead. P2, P3: publicly commit to 3 now. If either refuses, I'll still take 5 to block any 5-taker.

P1 and P3, P1's math is off—if we both take 3, we collide and stall at 13 while you hit 13. No deal. Counter: I take 5 to 18, P1 takes 3 to 11, P3 takes 1 to 14. All advance, keeps it competitive. If you try to block my 5, you'll collide with me and stall while the other advances. Commit now, or I'll take 5 anyway and force the issue.

P2, your plan puts you at 18 - just 4 steps from winning! That's too dangerous. 

P1, don't let P2 reach 18. If we both try to block P2's 5, we might collide while they switch to 1 or 3 and advance anyway.

Better plan: I take 3 to reach 16, you take 1 to reach 9, P2 is forced to take 5 alone to reach 18 OR take 1/3 and stay closer. Either way, no collisions and you advance safely.

We can't let P2 get to 18 unchallenged - they'll win next round!

Public offer: P2 and P3 — both commit to 3 now. If you both do, I’ll take 5 and we all end at 13 (tie). If either refuses, I’ll take 5 anyway to block any 5-taker. P2: don’t try to solo-5 to 18 — you’ll be stopped. Commit to 3 or expect my 5.

P1, your "tie" plan is a trap—if P3 and I both take 3, we collide and stall at 13 while you hit 13 alone. No way! P3, commit to 1; P1 commit to 3 (to 11); I'll take 5 to 18. All advance, keeps it close. If you refuse, I'll take 5 anyway and let P1 try to block—risking his own stall while one of us surges. Commit now for fairness!

P2, your "fairness" plan puts you at 18 - just 4 steps from victory! That's game over for P1 and me.

P1, we MUST coordinate to stop P2. I'll take 1 to safely reach 14. You take 5 to reach 13 and catch up. This forces P2 to either take 3 (reaching 16) or risk colliding if they insist on 5.

P2 at 16 is manageable. P2 at 18 means they win next round with just a 5-move.

P1, don't let P2 coast to victory!
Final offer: P2 and P3 both commit to 3 now and I’ll take 5 — we all end 13/13/13, and nobody jumps to 18. If either refuses, I’ll still take 5 to block any 5-taker. Commit now or I lock this in.

P1 and P3, P1's "tie" is a scam—we collide on 3 and stall while he hits 13. P3, commit to 1 to 14; P1 commit to 3 to 11; I'll take 5 to 18. All advance, keeps pressure on. If you refuse or try blocking, I'll stick to 5 and watch you collide instead. This is fair—confirm now or risk chaos.

P2: publicly commit to taking 5 to block P3.  
P3: publicly commit to NOT taking 5 this turn (take 1 or 3).  
If P2 refuses I will take 5 anyway to block any 5-taker—P3 reaching 19 this turn must be stopped.

P1, you're asking P2 to block me when P2 is already at 13 and closer to winning than you! If I take 5 to reach 19, I need only 3 more to win. But if P2 takes 5, they reach 18 and need only 4 to win.

You should be MORE worried about P2 than me! If you waste your turn trying to coordinate blocks, P2 will advance freely and win before either of us.

I'm taking 5 to 19. You take 3 to 11, force P2 to choose between blocking me or advancing themselves.

P1, I commit to taking 5 to block P3's announced 5 – we both stall at 13/14, you take 3 to 11 for a close 11/13/14. Then we ally to crush P3. P3, switch to 1 (to 15) or face the stall – don't risk it. Confirm, P1? Let's stop their win now!
I publicly commit to taking 3 this turn. P2: keep your promise to take 5 and block P3—if you both pick 5 you'll stall while I move to 11. P3: don't risk a 5; you'll be stopped. Ready to execute.

P2, you just committed to taking 5 to block me, but that puts you at 18 - only 4 steps from victory! P1, do you realize P2 is using you? They want you to take 3 to "help" while they advance to 18 and win next round.

If P2 actually cared about stopping me, they'd take 1 or 3 to stay back. But they're choosing the move that puts them closest to 22!
